sen.j: 佐久良 東雄（さくら あずまお、文化 (日本)8年3月21日 (旧暦)（1811年5月13日） - 万延元年6月27日 (旧暦)（1860年8月13日））は日本の幕末時代の国学、和歌。
sen.e: Azumao SAKURA (May 13, 1811 to August 13, 1860) was a Japanese classical scholar and poet in the end of Edo Period in Japan.
Azumao SAKURA (May 13, 1811 to August 13, 1860) was a Japanese classical scholar and poet in the end of Edo Period in Japan.
Azumao SAKURA (May 13, 1811 to August 13, 1860) was a Japanese classical scholar and poet in the end of Edo Period in Japan.

sen.j: 本姓は飯島。
sen.e: His real surname was Iijima.
His real surname was Iijima.
His real surname was Iijima.

sen.j: 東雄の他の通称に靱負（ゆきえ）、寛、静馬、健雄。
sen.e: He was commonly called Yukie, Hiroshi, Shizuma and Takeo in addition to Azumao.
He was commonly called Yukie, Hiroshi, Shizuma and Takeo in addition to Azumao.
He was commonly called Yukie, Hiroshi, Shizuma and Takeo in addition to Azumao.

sen.j: 雅号は薑園（きょうえん）。
sen.e: His pseudonym was Kyoen.
His pseudonym was Kyoen.
His pseudonym was Kyoen.

sen.j: 尊皇攘夷の志士として活動した。
sen.e: He acted as a loyal supporter of Sonno Joi (the doctrine advocating the reverence for the Emperor and the expulsion of foreigners).
He acted as a loyal supporter of Sonno Joi (the doctrine advocating the reverence for the Emperor and the expulsion of foreigners).
He acted as a loyal supporter of Sonno Joi (the doctrine advocating the reverence for the Emperor and the expulsion of foreigners).

sen.j: 常陸国新治郡浦須村（現・茨城県石岡市浦須）の郷士・飯島平蔵の長男として生まれる｡
sen.e: He was born first son to Heizo IIJIMA, a goshi (country samurai) of Urasu Village in Niihari District, Hitachi Province (present Urasu in Ishioka City, Ibaraki Prefecture).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He was born first son to Heizo IIJIMA, a goshi (country samurai) of Urasu Village in Niihari District, Hitachi Province (present-day Urasu in Ishioka City, Ibaraki Prefecture).
sen.cmt: 「現」はpresent-dayの方が分かりやすいです。
sen.e: He was born first son to Heizo IIJIMA, a goshi (country samurai) of Urasu Village in Niihari District, Hitachi Province (present-day Urasu in Ishioka City, Ibaraki Prefecture).

sen.j: 幼名は吉兵衛。
sen.e: His childhood name was Kichibe.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: His childhood name was Kichibe.
His childhood name was Kichibe.

sen.j: 生家は代々名主を務める家であった。
sen.e: His family served as a nanushi (village headman) for generations.
His family served as a nanushi (village headman) for generations.
His family served as a nanushi (village headman) for generations.

sen.j: 9歳で下林村の真言宗観音寺に入り、住職であった阿闍梨康哉の弟子となる。
sen.e: He entered into the Kannon-ji Temple of the Shingon sect at the age of nine and became a disciple of Ajari (a master in esoteric Buddhism; a high priest) Koya, the chief priest of the temple.
He entered into the Kannon-ji Temple of the Shingon sect at the age of nine and became a disciple of Ajari (a master in esoteric Buddhism; a high priest) Koya, the chief priest of the temple.
He entered into the Kannon-ji Temple of the Shingon sect at the age of nine and became a disciple of Ajari (a master in esoteric Buddhism; a high priest) Koya, the chief priest of the temple.

sen.j: 「万葉法師」との別名もあった康哉に従い、万葉和歌を学ぶ。
sen.e: Following Koya also known as "Manyohoshi (Buddhist priest with profound knowledge of Manyosyu)", he learned about manyo waka (poems in the anthology of early Japanese poetry known as "Manyosyu").

Under Koya, who was also known as "Manyohoshi" (Buddhist priest with profound knowledge of Manyosyu), he learned about manyo waka (poems in the anthology of early Japanese poetry known as "Manyosyu").
sen.cmt: 内容が伝わりやすいよう文構造を整理しました。
sen.e: Under Koya, who was also known as "Manyohoshi" (Buddhist priest with profound knowledge of Manyosyu), he learned about manyo waka (poems in the anthology of early Japanese poetry known as "Manyosyu").

sen.j: 15歳で得度し、法名を良哉、字を高俊と改めた。
sen.e: He entered the Buddhist priesthood at the age of fifteen, and then changed his name to Yoshiya as homyo (Buddhist name) and Koshun as azana (adult male's nickname).
He entered the Buddhist priesthood at the age of fifteen, and then changed his name to Yoshiya as homyo (Buddhist name) and Koshun as azana (adult male's nickname).
He entered the Buddhist priesthood at the age of fifteen, and then changed his name to Yoshiya as homyo (Buddhist name) and Koshun as azana (adult male's nickname).

sen.j: 文政10年、17歳の時には、減租を求めて蜂起した民衆を説得して沈静させ、さらに代官に直訴し、民を救ったという。
sen.e: When he was seventeen in 1827, he persuaded and appeased the people rising up to call for tax reduction, and furthermore made a direct plea to the local governor to save the people.

He is said to have persuaded and appeased the people rising up to call for tax reduction, and furthermore to have made a direct plea to the local governor to save the people when he was seventeen in 1827.

He is said to have persuaded and appeased the people rising up to call for tax reduction, and furthermore to have made a direct plea to the local governor to save the people when he was seventeen in 1827.

sen.j: 奈良の真言宗豊山派総本山の長谷寺にて仏道修行を行うが、1832年、康哉の没後に観音寺の第28代住職を引き継ぐ。
sen.e: He got Buddhism training in the Hase-dera Temple, the grand head temple of the Buzan school of the Shingon sect in Nara, and then took over as the 28th chief priest of the Kannon-ji Temple after Koya died in 1832.

He got Buddhism training in the Hase-dera Temple, the grand head temple of the Buzan school of the Shingon sect in Nara, and then took over as the 28th chief priest of the Kannon-ji Temple after Koya died in 1832.

He got Buddhism training in the Hase-dera Temple, the grand head temple of the Buzan school of the Shingon sect in Nara, and then took over as the 28th chief priest of the Kannon-ji Temple after Koya died in 1832.

sen.j: さらに1835年、25歳の折に、新治郡真鍋村（現・茨城県土浦市）の善応寺の第18代住職となる｡
sen.e: When he was 25 in 1835, he became the 18th chief priest of the Zenno-ji Temple in Manabe Village, Nihari District (present Tsuchiura City, Ibaraki Prefecture).
When he was 25 in 1835, he became the 18th chief priest of the Zenno-ji Temple in Manabe Village, Nihari District (present-day Tsuchiura City, Ibaraki Prefecture).
sen.cmt: 「現」はpresent-dayの方が分かりやすいです。
sen.e: When he was 25 in 1835, he became the 18th chief priest of the Zenno-ji Temple in Manabe Village, Nihari District (present-day Tsuchiura City, Ibaraki Prefecture).

sen.j: 真鍋村に移った20代の頃から藤田東湖、会沢正志斎、加藤桜老（儒学者、笠間藩士）､大久保要（土浦藩士、戊午の密勅に参画）、色川三中（国学者、幕府の醤油御用商人）、藤森弘庵（儒学者）らに学び、交友した。
sen.e: Since his twenties after he moved to Manabe Village, he had learned from and kept company with Toko FUJITA, Seishisai EIZAWA, Ourou KATO (Confucian scholar and feudal retainer of Kasama Domain), Kaname OKUBO (feudal retainer of Tsuchiura Domain joining a secret imperial decree called Bogo no micchoku), Minaka IROKAWA (Japanese classical scholar and soy sauce purveyor to the bakufu) and Koan FUJIMORI (Confucian scholar).

Since his twenties when he moved to Manabe Village, he had learned from and kept company with Toko FUJITA, Seishisai EIZAWA, Ourou KATO (Confucian scholar and feudal retainer of Kasama Domain), Kaname OKUBO (feudal retainer of Tsuchiura Domain joining a secret imperial decree called Bogo no micchoku), Minaka IROKAWA (Japanese classical scholar and soy sauce purveyor to the bakufu) and Koan FUJIMORI (Confucian scholar).
sen.cmt: 「真鍋村に移った20代」はwhenで表します。Sinceとafterを混在させると前後関係が混乱します。
sen.e: Since his twenties when he moved to Manabe Village, he had learned from and kept company with Toko FUJITA, Seishisai EIZAWA, Ourou KATO (Confucian scholar and feudal retainer of Kasama Domain), Kaname OKUBO (feudal retainer of Tsuchiura Domain joining a secret imperial decree called Bogo no micchoku), Minaka IROKAWA (Japanese classical scholar and soy sauce purveyor to the bakufu) and Koan FUJIMORI (Confucian scholar).

sen.j: この頃より東雄と号して歌人として知られるようになり、水戸学を学び、国学を講じた。
sen.e: Since then, he became known as a poet named Azumao and lectured on the study of Japanese classical literature while learning Mitogaku (the scholarship and academic traditions that arose in the Mito Domain).

Since then, he became known as a poet named Azumao and lectured on the study of Japanese classical literature while learning Mitogaku (the scholarship and academic traditions that arose in the Mito Domain).

Since then, he became known as a poet named Azumao and lectured on the study of Japanese classical literature while learning Mitogaku (the scholarship and academic traditions that arose in the Mito Domain).

sen.j: 学識を評価され、藤田東湖らに水戸藩への出仕を勧められたが固辞したという｡
sen.e: Since his scholarly acquisition was highly evaluated, he was encouraged to serve in the Mito Domain but he declined to do so.
Since his scholarly acquisition was highly evaluated, he was encouraged to serve in the Mito Domain but he declined to do so.
Since his scholarly acquisition was highly evaluated, he was encouraged to serve in the Mito Domain but he declined to do so.

sen.j: 1842年、善応寺住職を辞して江戸におもむき、矢ノ倉町（現・東日本橋）に移住。
sen.e: After he resigned as the chief priest of the Zenno-ji Temple in 1842, he went to Edo and then settled down in Yanokura-cho (present Higashi-Nihonbashi).
After he resigned as the chief priest of the Zenno-ji Temple in 1842, he went to Edo and then settled down in Yanokura-cho (present-day Higashi-Nihonbashi).
sen.cmt: 「現」はpresent-dayの方が分かりやすいです。
sen.e: After he resigned as the chief priest of the Zenno-ji Temple in 1842, he went to Edo and then settled down in Yanokura-cho (present-day Higashi-Nihonbashi).

sen.j: 平田篤胤の門にて国学を学ぶ。
sen.e: He learned the study of Japanese classical literature as a disciple of Atsutane HIRATA.
He learned the study of Japanese classical literature as a disciple of Atsutane HIRATA.
He learned the study of Japanese classical literature as a disciple of Atsutane HIRATA.

sen.j: 翌1843年6月、国学の復古を志し、勤王を誓うために還俗。
sen.e: On June, 1843, the following year, he quitted the priesthood to aim for the restoration of the study of Japanese classical literature and pledge his loyalty to the Emperor.
On June, 1843, the following year, he quitted the priesthood to aim for the restoration of the study of Japanese classical literature and pledge his loyalty to the Emperor.
On June, 1843, the following year, he quitted the priesthood to aim for the restoration of the study of Japanese classical literature and pledge his loyalty to the Emperor.

sen.j: その足で鹿島神宮に参詣し、桜樹千株を奉献する。
sen.e: He went straight to visit the Kashima-jingu Shrine and dedicated a thousand cherry trees to the shine.
He went straight to visit the Kashima-jingu Shrine and dedicated a thousand cherry trees to the shine.
He went straight to visit the Kashima-jingu Shrine and dedicated a thousand cherry trees to the shine.

sen.j: その桜にちなみ、佐久良靱負東雄に改名する｡
sen.e: He changed his name to Yukie Azumao SAKURA named after the cherry trees.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He changed his name to Yukie Azumao SAKURA named after the cherry trees.
He changed his name to Yukie Azumao SAKURA named after the cherry trees.

sen.j: （「靱負」（ゆきえ）には、雪のように潔く消える、という意味を込めている。）
sen.e: (Yukie means to disappear gracefully like snow.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: (Yukie means to disappear gracefully like snow.)
(Yukie means to disappear gracefully like snow.)

sen.j: この桜は現在も鹿島神宮の鹿園の反対側の森に「東雄桜」として残されている。
sen.e: These cherry trees have remained as "Azumaosakura (Azumao's cherry trees)" in the forest across the Rokuen (deer garden) in the Kajima-jinja Shrine.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: These cherry trees still remain as "Azumaosakura (Azumao's cherry trees)" in the forest on the opposite side of the Rokuen (deer garden) in the Kajima-jinja Shrine.
sen.cmt: 「現在も残っている」は動詞remainの現在形で表現できます。「…の反対側」の訳語としてacrossだけでは不十分です。
sen.e: These cherry trees still remain as "Azumaosakura (Azumao's cherry trees)" in the forest on the opposite side of the Rokuen (deer garden) in the Kajima-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: この時に東雄が鹿島神宮に奉じた祝詞「豊香島天津大御神乃大御社爾桜木殖奉留詞」は、明治維新後、福羽美静を通して明治天皇に天覧されることとなる。
sen.e: The Norito (Shinto prayer) dedicated by Azumao to the Kajima-shrine Temple, "Poetry to dedicate cherry trees to the shrine of Toyokashima Amatsu Omikami" was performed by Bisei FUKUBA with the Emperor Meiji in attendance.
sen.cmt: 祝詞の（のタイトルだと思うのですが…）訳は直訳です。
sen.e: The Norito (Shinto prayer) dedicated by Azumao to the Kajima-shrine Temple on that occasion, "Poetry to dedicate cherry trees to the shrine of Toyokashima Amatsu Omikami" was performed by Bisei FUKUBA with the Emperor Meiji in attendance after the Meiji Restoration.
sen.cmt: 「この時に」「明治維新後」の訳漏れを修正しました。
sen.e: The Norito (Shinto prayer) dedicated by Azumao to the Kajima-shrine Temple on that occasion, "Poetry to dedicate cherry trees to the shrine of Toyokashima Amatsu Omikami" was performed by Bisei FUKUBA with the Emperor Meiji in attendance after the Meiji Restoration.

sen.j: また1844年、水戸藩奥医師である鈴木玄兆の娘であり、鈴木宗與（『救民妙薬』の著者とは別人）の妹である輝子と結婚。
sen.e: In 1844, he got married to Teruko, a daughter of Gencho SUZUKI who was an oku ishi (inner physician treating the Tokugawa family) in the Mito Domain as well as a sister of Souyo SUZUKI (different person from the author of "Kyuminmyoyaku [household medication]").
sen.cmt: 救民妙薬の説明は<http://www.tpa-kitatama.jp/museum/museum_12.html>を参考にしました。
sen.e: In 1844, he got married to Teruko, a daughter of Gencho SUZUKI who was an oku ishi (inner physician treating the Tokugawa family) in the Mito Domain as well as a sister of Souyo SUZUKI (not the author of "Kyuminmyoyaku" [household medication]).
sen.cmt: 「別人」を直訳すると不自然です。
sen.e: In 1844, he got married to Teruko, a daughter of Gencho SUZUKI who was an oku ishi (inner physician treating the Tokugawa family) in the Mito Domain as well as a sister of Souyo SUZUKI (not the author of "Kyuminmyoyaku" [household medication]).

sen.j: 輝子との間に二男二女を儲けた（長男久丸は早世、次男は巌、長女は峯、次女は春）。
sen.e: He had two sons and two daughters of Teruko (given names Hisamaru, Iwao, Mine and Haru for the eldest son who died early, the second son, the eldest daughter, and the second daughter, respectively)
He and Teruko had two sons and two daughters (giving names Hisamaru, Iwao, Mine and Haru to the eldest son who died early, the second son, the eldest daughter, and the second daughter, respectively)
sen.cmt: 「彼と輝子」を主語にする方が自然で分かりやすい英文になります。「名前を与える」ですから過去分詞givenではなく現在分詞givingにすべきです。
sen.e: He and Teruko had two sons and two daughters (giving names Hisamaru, Iwao, Mine and Haru to the eldest son who died early, the second son, the eldest daughter, and the second daughter, respectively)

tit.e: After moving to the Kansai region
After moving to the Kansai region
After moving to the Kansai region

sen.j: 東雄は各地で尊王論を遊説していたが、1845年に一旦上洛し妙法院宮の家人となった後､和泉国大鳥郡（現在の堺市）に滞在し歌学を講じた。
sen.e: Although Azumao went around every place to explain the doctrine of the reverence for the Emperor, once he went to Kyoto to become the retainer of Myohoin no miya in 1845, he stayed in Otori District in Izumi Province (present Sakai City) to lecture on the study of poetry.

Azumao went around to every place to explain the doctrine of the reverence for the Emperor, but after he went to Kyoto to become the retainer of Myohoin no miya in 1845, he stayed in Otori District in Izumi Province (present-day Sakai City) to lecture on the study of poetry.
sen.cmt: 内容が伝わりやすいよう文構造を整理しました。Every placeだけでは副詞句にはならないので前置詞が必要です。
sen.e: Azumao went around to every place to explain the doctrine of the reverence for the Emperor, but after he went to Kyoto to become the retainer of Myohoin no miya in 1845, he stayed in Otori District in Izumi Province (present-day Sakai City) to lecture on the study of poetry.

sen.j: 同年、さらに大阪北久宝寺に移り、坐摩神社の神官を務めた。
sen.e: In the same year, he moved to Kita-Kyuhoji in Osaka to serve as a Shinto priest at the Zama-jinja Shrine.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In the same year, he moved to Kita-Kyuhoji in Osaka to serve as a Shinto priest at the Zama-jinja Shrine.
In the same year, he moved to Kita-Kyuhoji in Osaka to serve as a Shinto priest at the Zama-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 坐摩版と呼ばれる国学書の出版を行うとともに、惟神舎を開き国学・皇学を指導した。
sen.e: He opened a kamunagarasha (Shinto school) to teach the study of Japanese classical literature and Emperor-centered historiography at the same time as publishing Japanese classic literature books called the Zama version.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処「惟神舎」の説明は<http://www.stthomasu.ca/~parkhill/cj01/irepjb.htm>を参考に英訳を考えました。
sen.e: He opened a kamunagarasha (Shinto school) to teach the study of Japanese classical literature and Emperor-centered historiography at the same time as publishing Japanese classic literature books called the Zama version.

He opened a kamunagarasha (Shinto school) to teach the study of Japanese classical literature and Emperor-centered historiography at the same time as publishing Japanese classic literature books called the Zama version.

sen.j: また江戸の渡辺崋山邸で出会った和歌山池上村庄屋の南繁信と友好を深め、南家に滞在しつつ尊王思想の普及に努めた。
sen.e: In addition, he deepened friendship with Shigenobu MINAMI, the shoya (village headman) of Ikegami Village in Wakayama whom he met in the residence of Kazan WATANABE, and promoted the thought of reverence for the Emperor while staying in the Minami family.

In addition, he deepened friendship with Shigenobu MINAMI, the shoya (village headman) of Ikegami Village in Wakayama whom he met in the residence of Kazan WATANABE in Edo, and promoted the thought of reverence for the Emperor while staying with the Minami family.
sen.cmt: 「江戸の」の訳漏れを修正しました。
sen.e: In addition, he deepened friendship with Shigenobu MINAMI, the shoya (village headman) of Ikegami Village in Wakayama whom he met in the residence of Kazan WATANABE in Edo, and promoted the thought of reverence for the Emperor while staying with the Minami family.

sen.j: 当時、東雄が生活した茶室が現在も保存されている。
sen.e: The teahouse where Azumao lived in those days has remained now.
The teahouse where Azumao lived in those days still remains.
sen.cmt: 「現在も残っている」は動詞remainの現在形で表します。
sen.e: The teahouse where Azumao lived in those days still remains.

sen.j: 1854年、再度京都に移り、神祗伯白川資訓に白家神道を学び、神祗道学師の称号を受ける。
sen.e: After he moved to Kyoto again in 1854, he learned Hakke Shinto (白家神道) from Jingi haku (a chief official in charge of matters relating to Shintoism), Sukenori SHIRAKAWA and then received the title of the master of the way of worship.

After he moved to Kyoto again in 1854, he learned Hakke Shinto (白家神道) from Jingi haku (a chief official in charge of matters relating to Shintoism), Sukenori SHIRAKAWA and then received the title of the master of the way of worship.

After he moved to Kyoto again in 1854, he learned Hakke Shinto (白家神道) from Jingi haku (a chief official in charge of matters relating to Shintoism), Sukenori SHIRAKAWA and then received the title of the master of the way of worship.

sen.j: 妙法院宮に召されて中奥席格となり、皇学教授に任じられた。
sen.e: Being called by Myohoin no miya, he was given the rank of nakaokuseki (中奥席格) and appointed to a professor of Emperor-centered historiography.
Being called by Myohoin no miya, he was given the rank of nakaokuseki (中奥席格) and appointed to a professor of Emperor-centered historiography.
Being called by Myohoin no miya, he was given the rank of nakaokuseki (中奥席格) and appointed to a professor of Emperor-centered historiography.

sen.j: 1857年、妻輝子が死去。
sen.e: In 1857, his wife Teruko died.
In 1857, his wife Teruko died.
In 1857, his wife Teruko died.

sen.j: この頃、静馬あるいは健雄との通称を名乗り、薑園と号した。
sen.e: Around this time, he called himself as Shizuma or Takeo and used Kyoen as his pseudonym.
Around this time, he called himself as Shizuma or Takeo and used Kyoen as his pseudonym.
Around this time, he called himself as Shizuma or Takeo and used Kyoen as his pseudonym.

sen.j: その後、大阪に移り住み、1860年、桜田門外の変に参加した水戸浪士たちの支援を行うが、大阪に逃亡してきた高橋多一郎とその子庄左エ門をかくまった科により、3月23日に同志一同とともに捕縛され、松屋町の牢獄に繋がれる。
sen.e: After that, he moved to Osaka and supported Mito roshi (masterless samurai) who joined the Sakuradamongai Incident in 1860, but he was captured together with the entire comrade on March 23 and put in prison in Matsuya-cho for sheltering Taichiro TAKAHASHI and his son, Shozaemon who escaped to Osaka.

After that, he moved to Osaka and supported Mito roshi (masterless samurai) who joined the Sakuradamongai Incident in 1860, but he was captured together with the entire comrade on March 23 and put in prison in Matsuya-cho for sheltering Taichiro TAKAHASHI and his son Shozaemon, who escaped to Osaka.
sen.cmt: his sonとShozaemonは同格の名詞としてカンマなしで続けます。「大阪に逃亡してきた」は非制限用法の関係代名詞節で表します。
sen.e: After that, he moved to Osaka and supported Mito roshi (masterless samurai) who joined the Sakuradamongai Incident in 1860, but he was captured together with the entire comrade on March 23 and put in prison in Matsuya-cho for sheltering Taichiro TAKAHASHI and his son Shozaemon, who escaped to Osaka.

sen.j: 4月上旬には江戸伝馬町の牢獄に移送され、6月27日、獄中にて病死。
sen.e: In early April, he was sent to a prison in Edodenma-cho and died of disease in prison on June 27.
In early April, he was sent to a prison in Edodenma-cho and died of disease in prison on June 27.
In early April, he was sent to a prison in Edodenma-cho and died of disease in prison on June 27.

sen.j: 後世、東雄は｢吾徳川の粟を食わず｣と宣言して断食し、命を絶ったという説が流れた｡
sen.e: Later, there was a rumor that he went on hunger strike to take his own life, declaring "I will never eat Tokugawa's millet."
Later, there was a rumor that he went on hunger strike to take his own life, declaring "I will never eat Tokugawa's millet."
Later, there was a rumor that he went on hunger strike to take his own life, declaring "I will never eat Tokugawa's millet."

sen.j: 東雄の遺体は罪人として千住小塚原の回向院に埋葬されたが、明治2年（1869年）に水戸徳川家の援助により大阪天王寺の夕陽丘に改葬された。
sen.e: The Azumao's body was buried as a criminal in the Honjo-ecoin Temple in Senju kozukabara, and then reburied in Yuhigaoka, Tennoji in Osaka with the aid of the Mito Tokugawa family in 1869.
Azumao's body was buried as a criminal's in the Honjo-ecoin Temple in Senju kozukabara, and then reburied in Yuhigaoka, Tennoji in Osaka with the aid of the Mito Tokugawa family in 1869.
sen.cmt: 所有格の前に定冠詞は不要です。
sen.e: Azumao's body was buried as a criminal's in the Honjo-ecoin Temple in Senju kozukabara, and then reburied in Yuhigaoka, Tennoji in Osaka with the aid of the Mito Tokugawa family in 1869.

sen.j: 埋葬地が勧業博覧会の敷地となったため、明治22年（1889年）、さらに東成郡共同墓地に転葬される。
sen.e: Since the burial place became an industrial exhibition site, his body was moved to the Higashinari District public cemetery for re-burial in 1889.
Since the burial place became an industrial exhibition site, his body was moved to the Higashinari District public cemetery for re-burial in 1889.
Since the burial place became an industrial exhibition site, his body was moved to the Higashinari District public cemetery for re-burial in 1889.

sen.j: 明治24年（1891年）には靖国神社に合祀され、さらに明治31年（1898年）、従四位が贈られた。
sen.e: He was enshrined in the Yasukuni-jinja Shrine in 1891 and given jushii (Junior Fourth Rank) in 1898.
He was enshrined in the Yasukuni-jinja Shrine in 1891 and given Jushii (Junior Fourth Rank) in 1898.
sen.cmt: 「従四位」は大文字で始めます。
sen.e: He was enshrined in the Yasukuni-jinja Shrine in 1891 and given Jushii (Junior Fourth Rank) in 1898.

sen.j: 昭和7年（1932年）、かつて住職を務めた善応寺に改葬され、忠霊堂が建設された。
sen.e: In 1932, he was reburied in the Zenno-ji Temple where he used to serve as the chief priest, and then chureido (temple to enshrine the soul of person who fought for the loyalty) was built.
In 1932, he was reburied in the Zenno-ji Temple where he used to serve as the chief priest, and then chureido (temple to enshrine the soul of person who fought for the loyalty) was built.
In 1932, he was reburied in the Zenno-ji Temple where he used to serve as the chief priest, and then chureido (temple to enshrine the soul of person who fought for the loyalty) was built.

sen.j: 法名は回向院仮葬真道居士。
sen.e: His homyo (posthumous name given to a Buddhist) is Ekoin kasoshindokyoshi.
His homyo (posthumous name given to a Buddhist) is Ekoin kasoshindokyoshi.
His homyo (posthumous name given to a Buddhist) is Ekoin kasoshindokyoshi.

sen.j: 東雄の墓の隣には大久保要の墓も存在する。
sen.e: There is Kaname OKUBO's grave next to Azumao's.
Kaname OKUBO's grave is located next to Azumao's.
sen.cmt: 所有格のついた名詞をthere is構文の主語にすることはできません。
sen.e: Kaname OKUBO's grave is located next to Azumao's.

sen.j: 歌人として東雄は多数の和歌および長歌を残しており、1840年3月には歌集『はるのうた』を自ら刊行している。
sen.e: As a poet, he left many waka poems and choka (long poems) and published the collection of poetry "Harunouta (Spring poems)" by himself in March, 1840.
As a poet, he left many waka poems and choka (long poems) and published the collection of poetry "Harunouta (Spring poems)" by himself in March, 1840.
As a poet, he left many waka poems and choka (long poems) and published the collection of poetry "Harunouta (Spring poems)" by himself in March, 1840.

sen.j: 歌人の佐佐木信綱は『近世和歌史』の中で、東雄を「勤王家中第一の歌人」と賞賛し、万葉調の古調の中に爽快感があると評している。
sen.e: A poet, Nobutsuna SASAKI praised Azumao as the best poet in the loyalists to the Emperor and described his poems as exhilarating as well as quaint with a Manyo form in the "Kinsei wakashi (history of modern waka poems)".

A poet, Nobutsuna SASAKI, in the "Kinsei wakashi" (history of modern waka poems), praised Azumao as the best poet in the loyalists to the Emperor and described his poems as exhilarating as well as quaint with a Manyo form.
sen.cmt: 文末に置くと「『近世和歌史』の中で」の接続関係が不明瞭になります。
sen.e: A poet, Nobutsuna SASAKI, in the "Kinsei wakashi" (history of modern waka poems), praised Azumao as the best poet in the loyalists to the Emperor and described his poems as exhilarating as well as quaint with a Manyo form.

sen.j: 特に昭和初期にその評価は高まり、昭和17年11月には愛国百人一首の80番として、東雄の「天皇に仕へまつれと我を生みし我がたらちねぞ尊かりける」が採用されている（現代語訳「天皇にお仕えせよと私を生んでくださった私の母親は、なんと尊い人であろうか」）。
sen.e: As his poems were highly evaluated particularly in the early Showa period, his poem "How reverend Mother is because she gave birth to me to have me serve to the Emperor" was selected as 80th poem of Aikoku Hyakunin Isshu (One Hundred Patriotic Poems by One Hundred Poets).

As his poems were highly evaluated particularly in the early Showa period, his poem "How reverend Mother is because she gave birth to me to have me serve to the Emperor" was selected as 80th poem of Aikoku Hyakunin Isshu (One Hundred Patriotic Poems by One Hundred Poets).

As his poems were highly evaluated particularly in the early Showa period, his poem "How reverend Mother is because she gave birth to me to have me serve to the Emperor" was selected as 80th poem of Aikoku Hyakunin Isshu (One Hundred Patriotic Poems by One Hundred Poets).

sen.j: 東雄が幼少時を過ごした生家は、1944年に国の史跡に指定された。
sen.e: The birthplace where Azumao spent during his childhood was designated as a national historical site in 1944.
The birthplace where Azumao spent during his childhood was designated as a national historical site in 1944.
The birthplace where Azumao spent during his childhood was designated as a national historical site in 1944.

sen.j: 正面に長屋門を構え、中庭をへだてて茅葺平屋建の母屋を有している。
sen.e: It has a Nagaya-mon gate in front and a main building of a thatch-roofed bungalow with a courtyard in between.
It has a Nagaya-mon gate in front and a main building of a thatch-roofed bungalow with a courtyard in between.
It has a Nagaya-mon gate in front and a main building of a thatch-roofed bungalow with a courtyard in between.

sen.j: 母屋の向って右側には土間、左側にはいわゆる田の字型の配置をした部屋が見られる。
sen.e: There are a doma (dirt floor) on the main building's right and rooms arranged in the shape of rice field on the left.
There are a doma (dirt floor) on the main building's right and rooms arranged in the shape of rice field on the left.
There are a doma (dirt floor) on the main building's right and rooms arranged in the shape of rice field on the left.

sen.j: 母屋の建物時期は正確には明らかにされていないが、広間型の旧式の間取りや構造手法、表門の建立許可文書などから、18世紀中期から末期、宝暦から天明期の建築と推定されている。
sen.e: It is not clear when the main building was built, but it can be estimated to have been built from the middle to the end of the 18 century, or the Horeki period to the Tenmei period, judging from old room arrangement in an audience hall style, an architecture method and a construction permission paper on the front gate.

It is not clear when the main building was built, but it can be estimated to have been built from the middle to the end of the 18 century, or the Horeki period to the Tenmei period, judging from old room arrangement in an audience hall style, an architecture method and a construction permission paper on the front gate.

It is not clear when the main building was built, but it can be estimated to have been built from the middle to the end of the 18 century, or the Horeki period to the Tenmei period, judging from old room arrangement in an audience hall style, an architecture method and a construction permission paper on the front gate.

sen.j: 屋敷はもと恋瀬川付近の平坦地に建てられ、氾濫のために現在地へ移築されたと伝えられるが、それに関しては史料が残されていない。
sen.e: It is said that the residence was built on a flat terrain and then moved to the present place due to flood, but any historical materials about it has not been left.
It is said that the residence was built on a flat terrain and then moved to the present place due to flood, but any historical materials about it has not been left.
It is said that the residence was built on a flat terrain and then moved to the present place due to flood, but any historical materials about it has not been left.

sen.j: 飯島家は浦須村名主と鍛冶屋を兼業してきたが、明治初年頃に鍛冶屋を廃業している。
sen.e: The Iijima family was a blacksmith as well as the head of Urasu Village, but it closed the business in the early Meiji period.
The Iijima family was a blacksmith as well as the head of Urasu Village, but it closed the business in the early Meiji period.
The Iijima family was a blacksmith as well as the head of Urasu Village, but it closed the business in the early Meiji period.

sen.j: 建物も幾度かの修理を経てはいるが、常陸地方の旧民家の特徴をよく残しており、高い価値を認められている。
sen.e: Although the building was repaired many times, it remains characteristics of old residences in Hitachi Province and is highly valued.
Although the building was repaired many times, it retains characteristics of old residences in Hitachi Province and is highly valued.
sen.cmt: 「建物が特徴を保持している」ということなので自動詞remainではなくretainを用います。
sen.e: Although the building was repaired many times, it retains characteristics of old residences in Hitachi Province and is highly valued.

sen.j: 史跡（国指定） 佐久良東雄旧宅 茨城県石岡市浦須314-1
sen.e: National historic site: Old residence of Asumao SAKURA in 314-1 Urasu, Ishioka City, Ibaraki Prefecture
National historic site: Old residence of Asumao SAKURA in 314-1 Urasu, Ishioka City, Ibaraki Prefecture
National historic site: Old residence of Asumao SAKURA in 314-1 Urasu, Ishioka City, Ibaraki Prefecture

sen.j: 指定年月日 昭和19年3月7日
sen.e: Designated date: March 7, 1944.
Date of designation: March 7, 1944.
sen.cmt: こちらの表現の方が一般的です。
sen.e: Date of designation: March 7, 1944.
